description: From Middle English emperour, borrowed from Anglo-Norman emperour and Old French empereor (Modern French empereur), from Latin imperātor (“emperor; commander”), from imperāre (“to command”). Doublet of imperator.

entries.meaning: The male monarch or ruler of an empire.
examples: They asked Julius Caesar, the valiant Roman emperor, what was the best death. He answered, that which is unexpected, which comes suddenly and unforeseen

entries.meaning: Any monarch ruling an empire, irrespective of gender, with "empress" contrasting to mean the consort of an emperor.
examples: In 690 Wu usurped the throne and became Emperor herself, which proved a unique event in the history of China.

entries.meaning: (political theory) Specifically, the ruler of the Holy Roman Empire; the world-monarch.
examples: The Investiture Controversy was a conflict between the Emperor and the Pope.

entries.meaning: (tarot) The fourth trump or major arcana card of the tarot deck.
A large, relatively valuable marble in children's games.
Any fish of the family Lethrinidae.
(entomology) Any of various butterflies of the subfamily Charaxinae.
(entomology) Any of various large dragonflies of the cosmopolitan genus Anax.
